message: we use django-bloom plus a middleware that sets 'request.base_template', our normal base template "base.html" just has a single line in it: {% extends request.base_template|default:"base_desktop.html" %}
Is there any clean solution out there with Django-CMS to detect the browser and serve a mobile "geared" template as apposed to the normal template you'd serve if someone was surfing from a desktop?
@ojiidotch great. Thanks. Will give bloom a spin.
it's packaging is fail, so you'll probably need to copy it into your project
also it depends on deviceatlas, which is not free
we do want to make it easier though to do multi-device websites using the django-cms
basically the django-cms does not and will not do browser detection
there's no concrete plans yet, but you are free to join the discussion at https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/django-cms-developers/KTueGL9GJgw
@stardog101 Thanks for the info. Will definitely have a look.

@stardog101 Our use case that we currently have is that we have a client on Django-CMS and they've been happy. Now they want us to add functionality where they want to possibly show certain pages to mobile browsers and other not. The pages could be shared as well across all platforms though as well. So just checking what is out there at the moment before we tackle this :)

look at the ML thread I linked, thats more or less what we want to build into the CMS, but it'll take a while until we have that, since the scope of mobile support we want to support is not clear yet. for now we solve that by making the mobil navigation static.
